element_texts.text:
It will take you 4 yrs. to make anything of this; so take your time.
April 19, '77
466 SOUTH PRICE ROAD
ST. LOUIS, MISSOURI 63124
Dear Edith,

  I have carried your most recent communication of Aug 26, 1976 around with me, over hill & dale, on the ground, in the skies and on the water while fishing, ever since!
  Jabber Cherbousier whom you entertained so pleasantly at your Villa, asks about you often. The last query was in Florida this past month. She has a very delightful house on the island of Captiva. The house faces the Gulf of Mexico and the land or rather the beach in front of the house washes away periodically from heavy winter storms. This is a great expense and a worry, but she loves it and has nieces, nephews & friends to visit often.

P.S. Carol (my elder daughter) and husband planning to build a week-end residence out of N.Y.C. somewhere. Architect is a great friend of mine with impeccable taste and great talent - a former pupil of Frank Lloyd Wright. It should be lovely.

3
printed letterhead      466 SOUTH PRICE ROAD   ST. LOUIS, MISSOURI  63124
The Mo. Historical Assoc. building. I had rather planned to give a donation to the Lindbergh Memorial which is to be built in Washington I believe, but there goes part of it into the evening of May 11.

  Our museum is on its way to raising several millions of dollars for complete rejuvenation & additions and I am about to fly briskly and briefly to the Chicago Art Institute to see the TuTankhamen exhibit. This I have seen in Cairo but want to see how it is displayed in the U.S. and also simply want to stand and drool over the various pieces again, as I did before.
  In relation to the great energy crisis which is closing in upon this country, I've installed "reflective film" on all the front & largest windows of my house. These appear

pale gold on the exterior and simply cut the glare inside. The purpose: they now keep the furnace heat in in winter and the air conditioner cool in in summer. So both heat & cold air can now be cut down considerably. I'm told the house now gives the appearance of a house of ill-repute!

  And a man from an insullating company comes tomorrow to give me an estimate of adding greatly to the insullation in my attic.
  But what am I going to do with my legs when I have to move to a midget-size auto? If I fold them under I won't be able to emerge. If I stretch them straight out, they'll puncture the radiator. A real problem.
  Pres. Carter must have something in mind other than peanuts. I should drop him a note!
  No one -- but no one on the highways obeys the 55 mi. per hr. speed limit. 70 - 75 - 80 what's the difference?
  A great deal of love to you constantly. I wish I could see you. I think about you often and long. 

X X X Frances

2
printed letterhead
466 SOUTH PRICE ROAD
ST LOUIS, MISSOURI 63124
This is sometimes a worry too and always of course an expense. But she rushes back to St. L. and sells a couple of houses (real estate is her business). This seems to rejuvenate her. She is a great girl and smart. 

 Martha Jane, another St. L. admirer of yours, frequently enquires about you. She travels far & wide each winter to exotic spots and somehow spoke a good deal of French in Portugal and maybe Spain too this year. Don't ask me how all this came about. 
 And do you remember Polky? He & I are planning to attend the 50th anniversary dinner of Lindbergh's flight on May 11. Anne Morrow L. will be on hand and will see all her & her husband's medals & trophies displayed in a new setting at

P.S. spend this past week end at Martha's farm. Everything green beautiful and quite unkempt! Her herd of cattle had produced a great abundance of calves and a great Pyrenees dog came to visit and rested on Martha's stomach in bed in the night. She had to telephone the master at 12 midnight. He was so sorry, he had spent the day buying a horse. Where will underlined it sleep?

Pub. favorable to me?
Not so!
These are tech icalities
not ex. of, lice
Pref. by pub..c to
paying on damage
to remaining.
Offer of the whole
estate came later!

Date 24.5.68
Dear Dr Farnsworth./
I wonder if you remember me and the wonderful day I spent with you & Mies at your house before it was completed? I am prompted to write to you because I saw a note in Progressive Architecture that the authorities were proposing to build a bridge so near your house that you may have to leave it. After eighteen years this sounds awful and you have my complete sympathy should you have to leave this lovely setting. 

  My wife died early this year and I may come to the states later in the year to visit friends in California. If it were possible I would like to visit Chicago again and possibly to go and see you. I do so hope

you are well happy and busy. It is an awful long time since we last wrote - a Christmas card if I remember correctly.
With kindest regards and very best wishes, 
Your ever Frankland Dark.

CARTE POSTALE
Correspondance
Adresse
Dear Dr. Farnsworth,
I do hope that you will accept this publication as a memento of your commission! With all good wishes,
Peter

3rd March 1977.
Edith dear,
Enclosed a letter from Jaques Francais, with couple of other papers which all are fully self-explanatory. 

 As I really expected, he took the violin on consignment. And since it would be very difficult to sell the violin here, due to Hill's opinion, I fear you have not much of an alternative.  
 Just the same, you can still decide. My sister is coming to London on the 26th March and could bring the violin back if you wish. Also PLEASE let me know about the bow about which I wrote in my last letter (???) 
 We (Bab and I) are flying to Istanbul on Sunday the 6th will be back in London on the 10th March and off again for ?Cajues? on the 12th  March to the 26th March. You can contact me on the 11th March on from

the evening of the 12th March in  ?Cajues? 20-81-58, is our telephone number.

  Hope you are alright and the new couple (or couples) wonderful i.e. all you want. I really hope so for you.

Much love from both of us,
[signature]

Dear Edith-
At long last I take my pen in hand - Haven't been able to write letters at all - Never did much writing but old age seems to have stopped me completely - It is snowing - the first real snow storm of the winter - The weather has been beautiful clear, cold and sunny - I find living here very pleasant - There are lots of congenial people Then it is such a lovely spot - Aunt D is as busy and bossy as ever - She seldom sits down - Today is an exception and we are in front of the fire listening to the opera on the radio - 

  Poor Polly is not at all well now and won't go out at all except for a short drive - She has had me for dinner a couple of times but I think it is very tiring for her - Margaret had a breast removed before Xmas - Her memory is very sketchy but she is cheerful about it all and says quite often "there is nothing that I can recommend about old age - Geneva Sawyer really took care of her and then she died suddenly in the fall - So she is quite lost as all the people who had work for her for years are dead - Phyllis and Jim ?Ames? are the only ones left and they are attentive but of course not around much - Saw Jim and his new wife last fall they came up for Geneva's funeral - ?J.....? is very charming - his wife is gay and jolly so he is too - On Tuesdays Margaret has lunch with us and then we go to Jeannie's and play "Chele" a form of Canasta - On Sunday noon we have dinner with

Margaret  - and she entertains ten or twelve people - 
The Thomases have retired here and Tommy is managing the hospital - Their house is all fixed up with their [E**etes?] furniture and I feel the influence of their years in France - Very nice - 

 The shocker of the season is the crack up of the Clark Fitzgeralds - Do you remember the sculptor and his wife? I believe she said she had fallen in love for the first time in her life - They were married twenty seven years - Leah's intended is also married - a Mr. Good who was head of the Acadia Park and now is at the Yosemite - The two couples saw a lot of each other here - 
  The Frank Hatches are here Marjory doesn't go out much -  and Frank has trouble with his eyes and can't drive after dark - Barclay Robinson died last summer - 
  Lucy Flores daughter is married to a Greek artist and living in her mothers house this winter - Then there are lots of other people - so it isn't deserted - 
  I try to picture you in your villa or pallazzo - If you have any snap shots send me one - I have read the books by Howard Arlon and Iris Origo - So I picture you in the Bloomsbury group or what is left of it - Or are they too precious for you? More likely too ancient - 
 Last summer I went to my sister Sallie's ranch in Arizona - The day before Thanksgiving my sister Phyllis son was killed trying to get on a train after it had started - Otherwise nothing has happened to me worth mentioning -

I am sure you are writing but is it poetry or a novel? Aunt D wants me to tell you she read the book by the daughter of Ezra Pound - Have you run into her? 

  Is the Arno polluted? Pollution is the chief topic of conversation over here - 
 Am enclosing a snapshot taken at the ?Le Boutilliers? last summer - Ted's mother is very sick and he and Una are with her most of the time - Come back for a week every now and then - As usual  this letter seems to be nothing but vital statistics - I do want you to know that I think of you often and hope that you are enjoying the life in Italy - Your devoted ?Dode? February nineteenth

Dear Edith

               Here I am back in Castine -  It is

a foggy morning.  Ruthie has just called
to ask if anyone would like to ride with
her to Bucksport - Aunt Dorothy said no for
all of us - Hence I am taking a few moments
of quiet to tell you how very much I 
enjoyed my visit with you in your
beautiful home - Betsy is right the
flowers here do not have any odor any 
more -  When I think of your garden
and the delicious fragrance there
no where do you find it here -
Although you probably don't feel this way it
was so tranquil - the view, the castle  and
the house - It was also wonderful to find
you so spirited in spite of your health
I am like Margaret who finds no thing to
recommend in old age - you seemed the
same as ever.

   This was started a week ago in the meantime

my sister Sallie and her husband
have come to Mt Oakland House at Horick's
Landing and Aunt D has been in a tizzy,
They are far enough away so we don't see
them every day, but she is so full
steam ahead every minute of the day that
I find it tiring - Frederick Bartlett died
Saturday - He had been in a nursing
home in Bar Harbor for a couple of 
months

Betsy and Friskie moved into Peggys house
yesterday - Pouring rain, all June has been
this way - As I had such beautiful weather
in Italy it doesn't bother me as much as it
does most people - Alice Bowden told me to give
you her best wishes - Said she enjoyed you so
much that winter you spent here - saw
Fred Sweet the other day.  He is still the
golden haired boy

  Dear Edith thank you again for the

delightful visit - Pat Amy for me and give
my best to Dina and her husband
Love
Dodo
June 26th

I believe your letter was opened as it was
sealed with tape 
April 9th
Dearest Edith; - It is a strange thing that I had been
thinking so much about you and then your letter came.
Prehaps [sic] it is that now we are older (and did we ever
think in our wildest dreams that we would become this
old?) our thoughts go back to our earlier years.  I can remember
so many interesting things we did as children and
I remember your house and parents so vividly.  You all
must have been very good to me.  I spent so much time at the 
Astor Street house that I remember that very well also, and I 
clearly remember walking with you and telling you my mother
was dying.  Certain violin compositions bring back the times
you practised crossed out: your violin.  Then, of course, I remember a beautiful
Fall Sunday when Malcolm and I visiting you at your Mies
Vanderau (have forgotten how to spell his name,) and we worried
about the character that was being sought along the river
and you slept with a pistol!  Well, so be it for memories. They
are great things when they are happy.  I do not like you to
be so uncomfortable with what I assume to be your arthritis.
I remember you were miserable when I last saw you.  It is such
a pity no one comes up with a cure.  I am still healthy and count
my blessings.  I still live in a cottage right on the ocean and
hope I can stay here for the end of my days.  It belongs to the Casa
de Manana, a retirement set-up.  Unfortunately, it is in bad
financial condition and I am afraid will fold.  In this case
I can't imagine what all us old folks will do - particularly
those in their 90s.  This is a pretty posh area with few low
income housing for those that will need it.   I just live each 
day, playing golf twice a week, walking a lot, working
for causes and feeling grateful for friends.  Your letter makes
me feel more than ever worried about Italy and your
future comfort in your villa.  My sister gave me a detailed
description of it.  I would adore to see you and it but doubt
if I will get to Europe again.  There are friends of Louisa's in the
Paris area I would also like to see but doubt if I make it.
I came on my Italian diary the other day.  What a wonderful
school year I had!  We are all wondering how Mr. Carter will
work out.  He seems pretty brash at the moment but I am told
he is exceedingly bright and will learn fast.  My family are 
all fine and living good, constructive lives - all are very
creative - where they got this I don't know.  I will try to
keep more in touch with you, my dear.  I love you deeply
Your devoted friend, Frances
I am sending  your letter to Rachel.  She visited me this winter.  She is
just the same -

address side of air letter
postmark  SAN DIEGO, CA  10 APR 1977
[Stamped] USA/22c [Stamped]
Dr.  Edith Farnsworth
16 Via del Carota
50011 Antella
Florence

AEROGRAMME
VIA AIRMAL
PAR AVION
Second Mail
[Picture of Vibrant flowers on a table]

Jan 2nd
Ruthy dear,
Your Christmas note with the
news of Steve's death came as some what
a shock to us.  Having left L.F. 26 years
ago, I find it hard to realize that our 
old friends there also age, particularly 
Steve.  How you must miss him!  I
loved the picture of us at the bridge
table.

   I found Edith's memoirs had such 

gaps that I was not able to put them in 
order with any continuity
I imagine her illness 
with long periods of weakness
had something to do with it.

  I am apologetic at not

having sent you a card this
year, but I somehow imagined
you had gone to Italy.

  Fair is very lame and 

stooped as a result of a bad
fall, but always sweet and
amiable and tries to be 
helpful.  My eyesight is limited
but we are fortunate in being
very comfortable up on our hills
and are surrounded by beauty.

  Much love from us both.  Marion

[page out of sequence]
times to the family, and have
just had three weeks in there
with the boys vacation.  Very
strenuous but interesting.  I am
writing Hastily as am expecting
picnic guests any moment

  My little friend Mary Lord

lost her mother, last fall & is
now taking a trip west.  She
will be in your city for the
next two weeks c/o W.B Sturgis
2440 Lake View Ave, and if 
you have a moment and the
urge do see her, as she needs
a bit of cheering up.
My best to you and
family
Ruthie
Jan.  8, 1938

[page out of sequence]
Lincoln
Mass
Dear Edith

  Many thanks for the

Xmas card.  Was much cheered
over the prospect of more tennis
& the pleasant morning routine
again next summer  I too played
much better when I got home
onto really good courts.  Do bring
your fiddle too next summer.
I am living in the cutest wee
cottage out here in Lincoln , real
country.  Tommie as sole companion
Except for over night guests.  Doing
own work, Experimenting with wood carving &
practicing fiddle, much
outdoor, riding skating walking &
some skiing.  I love it.  Go in at

Dear Edith, Received the good message from
your friend, and skimpy as his report of you
was, I was glad to get it.

  A report on ourselves:  We are both somewhat

damaged goods having had a heart attack apiece
(each), and G, a broken hip in Marseille.  I 
must have written you about that.  We've cut
down by about 50% of the wild life we lived
before, which means turtlehood for both of us.
Its really a joke because, as you know we've
[underlined: Never] been very active.

     G. is as handsome as ever if not more so and

so far I'm holding up - Not more beautiful
and very little more or less passable.  However
there is still zest.

  G is writing his memoirs; I'm editor with

no training.  You can imagine the result.  I'm
afraid I demolish his latinized English to
replace it with pedestrian a current style, which
doesn't limp too much.

  Leon, my son, has written a very lively book

on car racing - auto biography of Peter Revson
since killed.  The book was well received but
has a limited audience.

  Leon's father, my ex husband, died in the spring.

I don't know whether I wrote you that I lost
Noel about 3 years ago; a dreadful blow
that I don't really get over.

   No one in our age group has married,

taken any new lovers except one, whom
you don't know but has taken a dark one.

We're going to the Poconos in July - August with
a Dr.  David Scherf and wife.  Do you know
him?  He is and was a very distinguished
cardiologist from Vienna.  He too is a cardiac
case; a very meticulous person, and maybe with
all those excellent qualities, he'll be able to
slow time a little.

  Dear Edith, I've thought of you very much;

forgive this intimate comfortable writing paper.
Let me know about yourself.  Are you imbued
with Italy, art and poetry and love I 
hope.
Our love to you
Edna -  Georges

La Taverniele
50011 Antilla
8/14/74
Carissimo Eugenio,

  ti scrivo queste parole - non

sacanno nemmeno parole benii ombe di parole,
niente che abbia del sense - sul quaderno appoggiato
sulle ginocchia.  Sul divano, accanto
a me, c'i Amy che gia dorme.

  La tartaruga, invece, e gia sveglia -mi

i venuto incontro sul ventiero l"attro giorno,
la testina fuori, le tre zampe da rettile protandolo
avanti con una velocita surprendente.
"Chi t'ha fatto quisto male?" gli chiedo per l'innesima 
volta.  "Is non posso rapportare le
evidenze del tuo male."  "Sei troppo sentimentale,"
mi respondono i piscoli oceni sentillante,
"Cosa vuol dire un piccolo seontro fra tanti
secoli?"  Eoggi sono rimasta colpita dal caso
del faggiano.  E'un maschio e fa il suo quartiere
generale con noi mentre circa la sua
femmina.  Pero al canto suo non si sente
nessuna risposta - pare che non rimanga 
una sola faggiana in tutta la Toscana.

superstite degli spari del 1973.

  I poveri Romanelli (ti recordi la sua che abbiamo trascorsa da loro?}  sono eaduti in tuti una serie di sciagure.  Sone arrivate la notte in casa loro i carabinieri e hanno ammarretti to il figliolo ventiduenne per l'uso di non so quale droga - e l'hanno buttato in carcere!  Pare che sia coinvolta anche la Ginevra (quilla che venne qui a chiedosti la firnice) e per cio non prio tornare dall'Inghilterra doon si trova ora, per la paura di andare in carcere anchi lir.  E intanto la povra Rolls Royce la quale ha una fiduccia simplicissima nellamagia, qualisiasi  magia, chiede alle larve - qualsiari larva - di rivelare qualsiasi cosa servendosi di tavoline agile che ballano e battono (Zauberberg!), di fili di cottone che, attaccati a un dito, ti spigano quello ch sarà o che non sarà.
   Oggi abbiamo commemorato l'ascenzione di Cristo in Paradiso.  A Washington i nostri amici studiosi, Continui e Singleton, in toga, passano per i viali

della capitale per commemorare l'incoronazione di Petrarca.  Contini acrà già letto la sua relazione, a cui ho sacrificato tre settimane della mia stanea e depressa vita.  Doveri assistere a nu paio di sedute fatte qui scollo stesso divano per lo scopo di convertire quella incredibili frasi di purissimo continere in u inglese che Londini stesso avieble la forza fisica di pronunciare!  E le digressione:  fiori per la Chiovenda, riverente menzione del padre e dello zio da lei - e tutto questi a Washington!

   Ora, carrissimo, parliamo di le.  Lei tue affettuosi parole mi confortano moltis. si mo e mi fanno venire.  La voglia di andare a Milano a trovarti.  Se io non fossi cosi debole cosi sofferente!  Mi trascino per le giornate i a bandono con sobliers, anzi con gioia, alla notte, la vista delle colline notturne e al suono delle civette.

[letterhead]   Eugenio Montale
Cara Edith

[letter has a line crossing it all out]
Dearest Bunny,
I am sorry not to have been able to reply sooner to your Xmas note. I have been laid up for a good many months and unable to use either a pen or the typewriter - 

  This will be brief and particularly for the purpose of urging you & Bill to make it to Florence to spend a few days here with me. I can't think of anything that would give me more pleasure -The political situation may give you pause but I don't believe that anything much will change this year which would affect visitors. So do come! With much love as always.

Mrs. HENRY GEERING
160 MAPLE HILL ROAD,
GLENCOE ILLINOIS 60022
[a line crosses out this letter]
Dear Genny,
Just a few lines to urge you & Henry to set your sails for Tuscany My delay in answering your Christmas note was due to physical disabilities & I hope that I am not too late in my invitation 

  It would be lovely to see you both & I shall be waiting to know when I may expect you. 
  I was of course delighted to know that Henry was better - Most affectionately

[[line drawn through text]
Mrs. Ambrose Chambers
North Olcott Ave
Chicago  Illinois  60634  USA
Dear Jacqueline,

  It is a long time since your nice letter arrived an I am sorry not to have been able to answer it sooner   I have been more or less disabled for most of the last winter & spring & correspondence is sitting in untidy & unanswered piles!   Your letter opened a long vista & I am glad to know that you are well & presumably Ambrose & the children
  You mention Stu Able and the quotes something he had to tell me -
   It was sweet of you to ask me whether I wanted to hear it - &

entire section has a slash going through it
I hesitated a little myself - But I think we can trust Stu;- so do give him my address & tell him that I will be glad to hear from him-
Do give my affectionate regards to all of your family & do let me hear from you now & again -
Fondly,

X through entire page
MRS JIM SALLEMI
615 BAYSIDE RD
BELLINGHAM
WASHINGTON
98225
Dear Jim,
I actually had a Xmas note to you all written which for me is rather a feat--and then I lost track of it in the confusion which resulted from my own prolonged illness. This is not exactly EFFICIENCY apartment. I have the impression that you and EMIL are very happy in your new home I hope however that that will not prevent you from planning another trip to Italy It would be lovely to see one or both of you here at Le Tavernule?
I was a little sad to think of the Borsellis

[[X through entire page)
in their retreat for the aged which I can imagine all too easily It seemed a great pity to give up their beautiful apt. in Rome and make the long transfer to the Pacific Coast - but Augusto was badly disabled & frankly & variable afraid that Terry Tessy? Gerry? would die FIRST & leave him alone in Italy I miss them greatly 
Do let me hear from you Jim
Affectionately,

ADD 
DATE
Dear Mr Trembley

  Thank you very much for 

your kind and explicit
letter of Jan 28th - It
brought me peace of mind
In view however of so many 
ambiguous factors I am
writing now to request 
the customary quarterly
bank statements covering
my own personal account
and that of the BATIFONSA
Perhaps you have already 
sent them and the
mail has let us down

however I have had
no further communications
either from you or
from Mr. Olivero and
am therefore out of
touch with the recent affairs.

  I understand that

the amount of the
"rental" of the house,
customarily forwarded
to GENEVE twice a 
year, is now matched
with a 50 per cent
temporary withdrawal
from my STEIN HAUSLIN A/C -  I
wonder if you would
have any suggestions
with regard to this
problem
With thanks
Cordially yours
